top_comment.text:
This is too difficult a question for me to answer, honestly. I get what 
turns people off about anime, but I think its hypocritical. Because there 
is SO MUCH PDA, there is so much violence and nudity (and it seems that 
Japanese don't curse the same way we do since there are few anime which 
have a lot of shitbombs and f-bombs unless in English) and there are so 
many taboos which Hollywood and the current TV industry in America 
covers...that it doesn't make sense to me how anime isn't becoming more 
widely known and acknowledged or fanservice/explicit sexual content and 
nudity is still an issue. And its not all men's fetish either, I have 
friends who are girls who LOVE that stuff and they aren't 100% lesbian 
either. And a lot of people have stopped watching cable and moved over to 
Netflix/Hulu, which now have original programming and HUGE selections of 
anime. But we are a country that elected Bush twice so...

And unfortunately, I want to like Toonami, but since I never grew up with 
it and hate a majority of the shows on there now like the Big 3, I know 
that it's just clouded up with so much damn nostalgia and people who won't 
let go of their childhood love for shonen even when they're already adults 
watching it at the most godforsaken hours of the night. None of that stuff 
interests me. I mean yeah, putting on Black Lagoon, Deadman Wonderland and 
Space Dandy (well maybe...) were good moves and showing Rebuild of 
Evangelion, Akira and the Trigun movie were also good moves...yet I don't 
know if I can expect them to put on the new Sailor Moon anime (or even the 
uncut classic which finally got relicensed), Gurren Lagann (even though 
they've had FLCL on for YEARS and Panty and Stocking/Kill la Kill are 
PERFECT for Adult Swim) and Madoka Magica (it's like Rebuild, FMA:B and 
Sailor Moon in a way, seriously think about it). No matter what people in 
the biz might actually think of them (Sailor Moon, Madoka and TTGL are so 
fucking big with casual anime fans, especially people who live near and 
around Hollywood).

I don't watch mainstream TV anymore, I haven't invested any time in Game of 
Thrones or Walking Dead or anything like that. All my dad watches is Castle 
and NCIS. I mean...truly, there are plenty of anime that Americans could 
like, but this Animation Age Ghetto bullshit is probably the exact same 
reason that the Oscars completely glossed over and didn't even watch Madoka 
Magica Rebellion and the Wind Rises.

Now does that mean I want live action adaptations of all the major shonen? 
No. But its going to happen no matter what. And if those doing well means 
that I MIGHT one day see stuff like Pacific Rim which is MUCH more mature 
than the stuff that comes before it...okay, sure.

Hmm...Del Toro is really stepping up to the plate here with a Monster live 
action special for HBO and (lol it won't happen or maybe it will) a live 
action Madoka Magica movie...well not really but...you know how it goes. I 
might be able to trust directors like him, he's apparently got a good track 
record.

And then there's the live action Eva movie which has been in the can 
forever which we don't know whether that's still even being made or not.

This is a very interesting question, Gigguk. I don't really have an answer 
for it. But I'm really grateful you bought it up since I had been talking 
about this with my dad for some time now. Thanks! :)﻿

top_comment.text:
This is only loosely related, but I think this is probably the best place 
to start this debate anyway so here we go. 

I think the best, most critically acclaimed anime are those that are NOT in 
anyway a depiction of traditional/stereotypical Japanese culture (e.g. 
highschool, everyone being ridiculously polite, large mansions with 
ricepaper walls) and are in settings that are completely out of what I 
assume to be the animators' comfort zones. Just look at the difference 
between Fate/Stay Night and Fate/Zero. Zero has NONE of the bits at insert 
generic teenager's name here 's house, and I think it's much better for it. 
Here's some more examples to back up my point:
Attack on Titan- medieval/steampunky goodness
Baccano- 1930's prohibition America
Black Lagoon (First Half)- Thai/Indonesian gang shithole 
Gurren Lagann- Post-apocalyptic in a kinda weird way
Steins;Gate- In Japan, yes, but inner city, apartment Japan, something we 
very rarely see
FLCL- Massive Iron Steam Thing Ville?﻿

top_comment.text:
As a gamer, trust me. You do not want anime to go mainstream. Oh sure, we 
get the occasional innovative game, but most of them involve zombie 
apocalypses, dystopian futures, or present day cities molded to fit the 
sandbox game genre. If it's not first person and gritty, it's 3rd person 
and gritty. Usually, a game will also feature a white, gritty, gruff 
stubbly man protagonist who is so full of grim determination that I think 
all antidepressant factories and psychedelic drugs have been eliminated in 
service of more god damn brooding.

Imagine if %90 of anime protagonists were grown up versions of shinji 
ikari. Hell, then imagine giant robots and superpowers being removed for 
the sake of arbitrary realism and instead we get scenes of people getting 
gas for their car or doing yoga.

Gaming, with the exception of the indie scene and POSSIBLY the JRPG genre, 
has grown stale. Most racing games aim to be realistic, with any arcade 
exceptions being long gone or subjected to lower budgets. Hell, even JRPGS 
have become more "Select move, watch cutscene" than anything interactive.

Hell, if anything, I wish more games would take cues from anime and stop 
taking themselves so seriously. I mean, Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon and Saints 
Row IV decided very wisely to follow the footsteps of Gurren Lagann in 
terms of throwing out logic and doing the impossible, but the sad thing is 
those are exceptions now. And people complained about SR's new direction, 
demanding instead that the series goes back to it's gangster roots for 
seemingly no other reason besides realism and being a GTA knockoff rather 
than a GTA contender.

Trust me, unless you want most of anime to rip off breaking bad or the 
walking dead but worse, you don't want this.﻿

top_comment.text:
The problem I have with anime is that the characters talk WAY too much. My 
father has been in the same room as I was whenever I'm watching anime, and 
he couldn't get himself into it. Granted, he knows that there are anime out 
there that aren't geared towards kids, but I find anime to be dialogue 
heavy as well, so there isn't a steady, constant flow to it which has an 
established balance between dialogue and action, you know what I mean?

I know that saying the characters "talk too much" sounds like a minor 
gripe, but I had to seriously think about it for a second at the time. 
There have been moments in anime where certain characters get philosophical 
for over five minutes or so, and there hasn't been any progress in terms of 
the plot. I sometimes feel like that many anime out there is a chore to 
watch because of these moments. It has heavily affected anime within the 
Action genre negatively as a result. I myself can't get into a lot of anime 
made fairly recently anymore in addition to the industry being mostly 
saturated (and you've made some great points about its image today). I end 
up having to watch anime made from the 70's, 80's, or 90's because of that.

That said however, I would be more than happy to share my love for whatever 
anime I'm watching if they are interested in it or if they watch it as 
well. If they aren't interested, you just have to respect their decision 
not to watch, but also be objective towards how they see anime in any shape 
or form. I also used to feel a sense of shame whenever someone walks in the 
room and sees me watch anime, but really, it's not as bad as you think. I 
watch Toonami every Saturday and yeah, my parents catch me watching it, but 
they don't question it.

What can I say, times have changed. Don't be afraid to express your 
interest in anime. You may never know when these people come waltzing into 
the same room as you are when you're watching an anime that will TOTALLY 
change the way they look at it. And lucky for me, it happened with Attack 
On Titan. My father was actually interested in it and the show itself 
wasn't as dialogue heavy. There's a reason why that show is such a big 
thing right now.﻿
top_comment.author: HistoMagouri

comments.text:

comments.author: Stan Marsh

comments.text:
I think the reason that so many anime are so dialogue-heavy is due to the 
nature of the medium they were adapted from. So many popular shows are 
adapted from manga or light novels, which are a literary medium. They rely 
on the written word to explain to the reader what is happening. This is 
perfectly fine and feels natural if being read, but when made into dialogue 
in a TV show can take viewers out of the moment. Also, since a lot of anime 
is fairly low-budget, it's a lot cheaper to draw people talking about the 
plot than to show it actually happening.

top_comment.text:
If anime becomes mainstream, it becomes the victim of stakeholders. Yes, 
anime companies are still companies so of course they have things like 
stakeholders, fancy business men, etc. It already does go through changes 
because of people wanting money, but when something goes mainstream in 
America, you might as well say all hope is lost. In modern America 
entertainment (Televised) this is how things are saw: The cartoons are for 
the kiddies and the shows on AMC, HBO, etc., are for our teenagers and 
adults. This is why anime isn't really mainstream (except product wise but 
oh well to that) because most of the viewers of the popular content in 
America instantly classify it as a cartoon, so they figured it'd be left 
for the kiddies. That said, no company would really want to produce any 
sorta anime in hopes of it being mainstream. This is why most of it, if not 
all, anime comes from Japan: where it grew. Many of us 'different' people 
who are different because a lot of us aren't 100% washed up in the damn 
'mainstream,' like anime because it's unique style. Anime was beginning 
when animation as a whole was taken flight in Japan around the 40's. Japan 
was looking toward Russia and America for ideas on how to style their 
cartoons, and eventually the young innovators of the time, such as Hayao 
Miyazaki, were creating things with a different style that became so 
popular in Japan during a bad time for animation. That's why anime stuck 
there, and so that's why "geeks" "nerds" and "weeaboos" love the anime 
style, and that's why it's not mainstream, and I don't think it ever will 
be. Because most "geeks" and "nerds" (excluding weeaboos this time) are 
people that have larger horizons in their cultural interest, therefor it's 
our type of interest that makes anime not mainstream because it is 
supported, loved, and driven by people who aren't washed in the mainstream. 
If this paragraph isn't convincing enough, then just look at America's 
trends: All girls of any age are wanting to shake their ass for "fun", all 
guys want to dress up in fisherman vest and wear caps of teams that come 
from sports they didn't know existed, and the favorite type of music is 
about sex, drugs, being better than you, and sluttiness. So I don't think 
anime could stand a chance of being mainstream in America, and if it ever 
does it will be short lived.﻿

top_comment.text:
Hmm, well the real issue here is that in Japan, being young is something 
they want to embrace. The reason shows that are "less mature" towards an 
audience like North America, where our mainstream media is pervaded by 
serious and often violent shows, is due to this partiality the Japanese 
have towards being young. The notion of the attraction to "cute" things and 
the desire to look young is quite pervasive in Japan (I've lived there for 
around 8 months, and I'm not trying to sound like an asshole here, I'm just 
trying to provide a bit of meaningful backing.) and hence their media often 
exudes this feel.﻿

+Caldera11 Thing is, I consider anime a style, rather then where it comes 
from. It was always silly to me that it can only be anime if it is Asian, 
as if people are saying USA can't make anime-styled things. I really 
disagree about calling RWBY not anime. Same thing if a American person drew

comments.author: Quincy

comments.text:
+Quincy It's not really "anime" (the japanese term for animation in Japan) 
so much as serious animated series in North America. Animated series are 
associated with childishness in North America, but the thing is, animation 
is a method of presenting themes and ideas that just don't work in 
cinema/film series with real people. Look at the short film "Out of Sight" 
as an example. Rather than going overboard on special effects to achieve 
these sort of things in real-life manner, animation can do it in a 
beautiful, more visually appealing way.

anime-culture-influenced population becomes older. With the dawn of 
projects like RWBY wishing to bridge the gap between Japanese animation and 
North America, bringing us simply "Meaningful, story driven animation" 
--the essential reason people watch anime (at least I hope...)--the idea 
that this sort of thing can only come from Japan (as much as I am a fan of 
Japanese culture, I have faith that a studio in North America could achieve 
something similar, like the show Reboot, that had great, story-driven plot 
and groundbreaking 3D animation for the mid-90s) begins to slowly fade.

I don't really care if it becomes mainstream. I want it to be accepted as 
an artistic medium and for it to grow as one. Same thing with games. I 
think games are slightly ahead of anime in this regard, because games have 
more appeal to the west than anime does. But I think neither industry has 
really gotten there yet. Yes we see games like Bioshock and the Last of Us 
and Papers Please once in a while that show that games can improve as an 
artistic medium, but these types of mature games are more like diamonds in 
the rough. Same thing with mature anime like Kino's Journey and AnoHana and 
Clannad, and Madoka Magika, and Terror in Resonance, etc. 

I hope that in the future, both these industries can be similar to 
Hollywood or the book industry, where you get multiple mature movies/books 
every year. I hope the same thing can and will happen to these 2 mediums. ﻿

comments.author: EdolasAnime

comments.text:
+EdolasAnime
I was introduced to anime because of One Piece and Naruto in my youth, so 
they still hold a special place in my heart... However, I don't believe 
with shounen you have to pick a side between "love it and watch it or avoid 
it".

I might be an anime fan, but I don't have the time to watch all of the 
long-running series as anime. Generally speaking, I read the manga for 
those longer ones (One Piece, Fairy Tail, Naruto, Bleach) because you avoid 
all the filler, it's far less of a time investment than the anime, and it's 
still the same content with all the same characters, and all the same 
plots, etc. I miss out on the animated fight scenes, but, meh, I don't find 
it to be that big of an issue when that's just an added bonus, rather than 
the main reason you should be judging or watching a show for in the first 
place (and I can always just watch the fights somewhere online anyway, once 
they come out in the anime, so it's not really a disadvantage either). What 
I'm getting at is that there needn't be a divide that strict when there are 
multiple mediums you can use to enjoy the same thing. Perhaps the anime 
isn't for you, but the manga is. Many anime fans forget that their favorite 
series are often (and overwhelmingly) adaptations of manga, so going back 
to the original content IS a legitimate option... (Some people don't like 
reading...and that's fine, but it does have it's advantages, and should be 
at least considered on that merit.)

Yes, Bebop and FMA accomplished more things in less time, but I wouldn't 
say they accomplished the same things in less time. Naruto's story is about 
the estrangement of people and how people can overcome that estrangement. 
It's one of the best I've seen when it comes to that specific topic alone. 
Bebop (to my memory, it's been a LONG time) wasn't particularly about that, 
and neither was FMA which delved into the value of a human life/soul more 
than anything. I may have seen about half as many series as you have (more 
than 100 more than the other guy), but I can still see the individual value 
in a series, rather than their relative value. Every series is unique 
enough that it offers something others don't. You just have to find out 
what that is.
comments.author: TheAlphaGeeks

comments.text:
+FrostWolfGaming1 I'll pass, i'm happy with the shounen anime i currently

comments.text:
+darkfur3 Long running shounen suffer from alot of all that^^ It takes a 
shit ton of episodes to complete simple tasks and many are subject to 
filler and story fatigue, I have never watched Bleach or Naruto so its 
unfair of me to give my personal opinion on them, but i can just about 
handle all the filler from my favourite shounen - fairy tail - so if Naruto 
has MORE filler i will probably drop it quick fast, so why bother?:') 
Bleach never really cut it for me and with the whole argument of it getting 
boring, i wont watch that either :P None of the big 3 should be considered 
'bad' anime, but definitely because of the filler, story fatigue and the 
fact that because they are gateway anime, are comprised of HUGE fanbases 
full of people who have a highly limited knowledge of anime as a medium, 
they should by no means ever be considered among the best

for that, my opinion on shounen will forever remain the same; highly 
enjoyable, but the fanbases are a mess.

+insertaghere Ok then. In that case the anime is as Urek so kindly 
volunteered.. "My little sister can't be this cute". The plot revolves 
around two siblings who harbor a typical amount of disdain for eachother. 
Who are forced to work out their differences once the brother finds out 
that his sister is a gigantic otaku (pervy nerdy Japanese anime/hentai fan 
of, and everything else to do with the genre) specifically she's obsessed 
with animated novels and interactive games, all of which revolving around 
the theme of brother sister incest. Yup. Right off the bat the brother 
fears for the worst as most of them have an older brother younger sister 
theme ( he's the older bro). The sister however quickly assures him 
otherwise. At first they don't let on anything for eachother. But you can 
tell it's there throughout the series. Their bond eventually grows stronger 
as they learn to live with eachother. Eventually they seriously start 
liking eachother. And you can kind of guess where it goes from there. It's 
available all over the internet if you're interested in watching it. The 
first season isn't actually too bad. And isn't graphic if I remember 
correctly. I haven't watched the second season yet though.. I hope that 
answered your question. And I hope after this you don't look at your 
brother through a different lense lol.

top_comment.text:
Here's what I think Gigguk. Anime is just not destined to be main stream. 
Before I go into why, I'll give you a little history lesson.

In the U.K. during the mid to late 1990s, mainstream media started taking 
an interest in anime, mostly likely due to Manga Entertainment (Manga Video 
then). Channel 4 even screened anime late at night, namely Legend of the 
Four Kings and Cyber City OEDO. Newspapers published articles on the 
subject and Jonathan Clements became editor of a magazine called Manga Max.
In fact, BBC2 once screed the film Wings of the Honneamise, which my mum 
taped for me.
After a while the media just stopped giving a shit about anime. Manga Max 
folded and newspapers just didn't even bother with it anymore. Although 
after the "Anime Boom" it seemed like Anime would be returning the public 
attention. Jonathan Ross presented a Japanese culture series called 
Japanorama and in 2005, Neo Magazine was launched and it still running to 
this day. Even manga was in high demand as bookstores started stocking 
loads of titles. Sci-Fi Channel U.K. started screening anime late at night 
also.

But in the end, the media and general public just didn't care. Anime and 
manga just faded into that niche part of geek culture and that's where it's 
gonna stay.
Anime is just not destined to be mainstream. And no Attack on Titan or even 
Neo magazine is going to change that.﻿

top_comment.text:
I watched this rant and my answer to the question, "*Do you want anime to 
become mainstream?*" is yes.

Most people's response to this video is, "NO! Then anime will lose it's 
uniqueness and all creativity will be lost!" but that's not necessarily 
true.

Sure, there will be the typical *Shonen* anime (Naruto, Bleach, One Piece, 
etc) that are already heavily pushed on the general audience, but that 
doesn't mean that creativity or the niche culture will suddenly vanish.

Much like any medium, there will always be a small group of people 
dedicated to a certain interest or genre. In music, while pop music tops 
the charts, lesser known artists are still selling tickets for venues. 
There are even "sub genres" of other genre's sub genres, that have devoted 
followers and still push out CD's. Anime isn't any different.

The animation studios that target larger audiences are like the studios 
that produce Hollywood blockbusters for the masses. If anime becomes 
mainstream, the animated blockbusters will be fairly generic and will make 
millions of dollars at the box office. Animated series will have massive 
followings that will either tune in every week to catch the latest episodes 
or will buy the whole series.

The smaller animation studios that target niche audiences will still have 
the freedom to deal with dark and controversial material, and explore 
different animation and storytelling techniques.

It'd be nice to be able to walk down the street and hear people talking 
about the latest Attack on Titan episode, or which anime they are most 
excited for next season, and be able to discuss the same thing with other 
people without needing to explain *WHY* you watch anime.

What are your thoughts on anime becoming mainstream?﻿

much that they turn to the blockbuster formula. at least if they keep the 
stereotypes I have more people to argue with!
comments.author: Pedro M. Polanco

comments.text:
The anime clubhouse mentality goes really deep, it bothers me when people 
approach anime on anime's terms as opposed to TV/Animation/Film.   For 
instance calling something that in any other medium would be referred to as 
a drama a "slice-of-life" show or fansubbers who don't translate well known 
subcultural phrases like baka and neko or senpai.  Its kind of frustrating.

I personally would be happy if anime were right on the edge of mainstream, 
acceptable enough to allow for things like Cowboy Bebop to be produced on a 
regular basis but not mainstream enough to fall into the Hollywood 
blockbuster formula.  Look at how watered down Steamboy was, as its 
probably the closest thing anime ever did to try to appeal to mainstream 
american audiences, and consequently it was a failure both artistically and 
commercially.

Seeing anime become so niche that its insular is terrible because the 
fandom will dictate what gets produced which is sadly what's happening 
right now, its not something that should continue - I hope what's going on 
in the game industry happens in the rest of media - the indie game 
revolution has gotten me back into videogaming after many years being 
dormant - its that exciting and wonderful :)
comments.author: Neil Clingerman

comments.text:
Maybe it's stereotyping, but the special clubhouse people tend to be from

that's when they can better support growing anime instead of protecting 
their social status niche.

But with that growing up will come natural attrition, so it's a give and 
take.

+Sean Bires You make a valid point that fans in the west are attracted to

reality is what makes me a fan of not just anime, but Asian cinema as well. 
There definitely is an audience that prefers that instead of the *hoorah - 
gotta get the girl and save the world all on my own* hooplah that is found 
in many western films.

As +LeVar Bouyer mentioned in his comment, the "special clubhouse" 
mentality towards anime is quite bothersome. It's as if watching anime is 
an elite hobby that the general public isn't allowed to participate, in 
fear that they will "tarnish" it's creative and storytelling aspects.

I'm hopeful that one day anime will be recognized for it's ability to

comments.author: Johnny Jones-Ransom

comments.text:
+Sean Bires Fair enough. Perhaps I'm just more worried than you about the 
possibility of "the tail wagging the dog" so to speak. I don't think the 
medium of anime would have to lose it's cultural core, as you say, in order 
to be diminished by trying to play to the global marketplace. I'm not 
worried about the real niche stuff going away, that's not going to happen, 
but more about the types of examples you specifically brought up, the *Spirited 
Away* s and the *Ghost In The Shell* s, being warped in a misguided attempt 
to appeal to Western audiences, something that I don't think ever occurred 
to the creators of either of them, but in the future, who knows? In my 
opinion, the entire concept of something being appealing to Westerners 
*because* of instead of in spite of its cultural quirkiness is an idea that 
will just not fit into the head of a Western media executive. The more 
people like that get there paws on these things, the more damage is done. 
The appalling and disastrous attempt to localize *Cardcaptor Sakura* is a 
good, if somewhat extreme, example of this actually happening. Contrast 
that to *Sailor Moon*, which mostly sort of sneaked in under the radar 
(there were definitely significant cuts and changes in the US version, but 
not complete rape as with *Cardcaptors*), and was a huge hit with boys and 
girls alike.
comments.author: Jack Bringloe

comments.text:
The thing is to "true" fans of anime, the cultural core is already lost on 
productions that pander to the otaku community, ones that are full of 
shonen action, are repetitious magical girl fantasies and what not.  There 
really isn't this singular concept of "anime" that can be identified 
*except* by those looking in from the outside.  Their view is so myopic, 
that they think things aren't mainstream simply because it's not popular 
amongst their peers.

Broadcasting and distribution do help, but they still wont make things 
acceptable.  Not everyone talks about Breaking Bad, True Blood, Lost, 
Sopranos.  There are always niches and fads come and go, whether in 
"normal" TV or within anime.  Perhaps there will indeed be another wave 
that brings Anime to the forefront of TV, perhaps there wont be.  At the 
moment, that's controlled by the broadcasters, and until those broadcasters 
figure out that it can be profitable, they really wont be inclined to 
popularize it (hint: they dont think it's worth the trouble or trying to 
cross localization and cultural barriers and to gain advertiser dollars and 
subscriber money).

So, perhaps, the next wave that anime can ride in on will be, as +Jack 
Bringloe implied in the shared post, when the current broadcast models die 
off, something like kickstarted kicks in, and people who want to watch 
something interesting have access to a legitimate source that wants to feed 
it to them instead of the current mainstream sources that dont want to 
bother.

Subbers have tried, even crunchroll is making *some* headway, but that's 
mainly to replace the subbers.  The method of deliver is still niche and 
the TV and the broadcasters controlling the contents that appear on there 
are still king.  Until that changes, it wont matter if you want Anime to go 
mainstream or not, it simply *wont* happen.

Though I guess there's still the movie route, and albeit a singular 
instance, something like Ghibli and Disney's partnerships can help.  But 
even then, I feel like that is simply being run by a core few people in the 
Disney hierarchy that really really want it to be so, not as a company 
philosophy as a whole.  But it has to start somewhere I guess.
comments.author: wara zashi

comments.text:
I find it really hard to imagine that anime would go super duper globally 
mainstream to the extent that it loses its cultural core. Telling stories 
with densely symbolic imagery is very... Japanese. Or at least not very 
western, where there's a preference for heightened reality rather than 
abstraction. I imagine overseas fans of anime are those who are attracted 
to eastern/Japanese aesthetics & storytelling at some conscious or 
unconscious level, separating them from the proverbial Joe Sixpack who will 
never venture beyond domestic film/television.

That cultural core, centered in Akihabara, Japan, will always be there, 
creating insular, referential genre hits like *Evangelion* and *Madoka 
Magica* and gobs of moe/bishoujo anime. But I also want there to be a space 
for creators that do not speak to that particular core, like Masaaki Yuasa 
(Kaiba, Kick-Heart) and Shinichirou Watanabe (whose Cowboy Bebop & SamCham 
were popular in the west).

And the past titles that have found mainstream critical acclaim overseas 
aren't culturally generic, necessarily. *Princess Mononoke* & *Spirited 
Away* are pastiches of Japanese folklore. *Akira's* urban apocalyptic 
vision is distinctly Japanese. *Millennium Actress* and *Perfect Blue* 
depict Japanese celebrities. *Ghost in the Shell* (the 1995 film by Mamoru 
Oshii) brought eastern spirituality and heavily symbolic, Japanese 
storytelling to cyberpunk, inspiring further sci-fi cinema in the west. I 
think that sort of un-core anime needs help (Ghibli aside) from fans 
overseas. That's where some degree of international "mainstreaming" can 
help diversify the output of the industry.
comments.author: Sean Bires (Renzu)

comments.text:
I guess looking aside from the fact that it's already mainstream in the 
economy that currently matters to the producers, the rest simply becomes 
that clique/niche mindset of people wanting to feel "special" for being 
part of something before it went "mainstream".

Culturally, there's almost too much nuance/culture/acceptability embedded 
in the current way anime is created and produced to transfer it to a 
different culture that wont have that same history and acceptance.  So as 
it stands, anime as a whole wont make it to non Japanese shores in the same 
way as it is being produced in Japan.

That being said, I do think something like Little Witch Academia via 
Kickstarter starts to prove an interesting point that there can be a paying 
market for something that can be funded for overseas export, even if it 
apparently didnt do to well domestically.

This may not be so much about content production as it is about finding 
ways to get select pieces distributed to audiences outside of Japan.  Any 
distribution company will usually have to spend their overhead to target as 
wide of a net as possible and that just wont cross the cultural gaps too 
well.  Focus needs to be small and tight to select groups, and that 
usually, as maybe the Kickstarter proved, needs to have a direct audience 
to producer relationship cutting out the middle distributor and enabling 
direct access.
comments.author: wara zashi

comments.text:
I'm not sure exactly what it is meant by "mainstream." Certainly within 
Japan, anime has and continues to be very much a mainstream entertainment 
product. And a money-making product as well, despite all the gloom and doom 
one hears. Ultimately a better question might whether the production and 
business models that produce such a glorious array of creative weirdness 
will scale to the international level. I'm sorry, but I do not think they 
will.

That is not to say that it is a bad thing for the Japanese to target an 
international audience to some degree, and this is definitely happening 
more than it used to. It seems to be becoming more frequent that shows that 
are huge hits in Japan are hitting big overseas as well (e.g. *Shingeki no 
Kyojin*). However if overseas income was an overriding concern, I feel it 
would dampen down the creative "furnace" of the industry to the point where 
the product would become unrecognizable. All *Shingeki no Kyojin* and *One 
Piece*. No more *Madoka* or *Penguindrum* or *Jinrui wa Suitai Shimashita*. 
Forget about VN or Bishoujo game adaptations. Certainly material like 
NisioIsin's Monogatari  series or the bulk of Type-Moon's output would be 
completely unacceptable. No thanks...
comments.author: Jack Bringloe

comments.text:
One of the industry's pluses is how it produces glamorous sci-fi & fantasy 
with visually sophisticated storytelling on the cheap, allowing it to cater 
to niche (i.e. non-mainstream) audiences. I don't think "going (globally) 
mainstream" on the level of Hollywood blockbusters or top-tier TV series is 
necessary or even possible. I think the ideal place for anime to be is to 
attract a broader audience overseas and (with the potential revival of the 
Japanese economy) re-attract a mainstream domestic audience. When creators 
can find revenue from a spectrum of mainstream audiences (as with "daytime" 
anime), niche crowds ("late night" anime), domestic (e.g. moe/bishoujo 
stuff), and global *(Kick-Heart, LWA, Space Dandy, Ghost in the Shell),* 
then we'll have a vibrant and diverse industry. I don't really care about 
living in a world where I can casually talk to my relatives about the 
latest anime. I only want the industry to be artistically vibrant.

Arguably something like that is starting to happen in the video game 
industry, which for the past decade has been driven by stale blockbusters. 
Now there's the beginnings of a renaissance in the industry with new 
business models (Steam, Kickstarter), paradigm-shifting technologies 
("cloud" services, mobile devices with cellular data, Oculus Rift & the 
return of VR), and a complex upheaval in the gaming culture itself.

I think the video game industry is going to get to that ideal place where 
games of all types, at all levels of production, from studios and 
individuals all over the world, are being made for diverse audiences. And 
the anime industry (certain companies, certain studios & creators) is 
giving the international market another stab. Kickstarter is a thing, but I 
think it's no accident that *Space Dandy* was unveiled in the US, and it 
looks to be exactly the sort of hip, exportable product that I want to see 
lead the rest of the industry. I hope anime gets to that place someday soon.
comments.author: Sean Bires (Renzu)

comments.text:

con). 

Will anime become as popular and talked about in the US as, say, the last 
episode of *Breaking Bad*? Almost certainly not. But I'd be satisfied if it 
got past the stage of "oh, that's them Jap porn cartoons, right?" The 
situation has improved from, say, ten or twenty years ago, but still.

top_comment.text:
Mainstreaming Anime.

Here, here, the usual "Should Anime Go Mainstream" debate.  Sort of.  If you ignore the personal niche, "I need to feel special" issues that some members of the vocal community keep advocating, you have a much more complex issue of how to create and distribute anime that can indeed work for a larger audience.

It may not necessarily be about content, as things like Shingeki No Kyojin, Kotonoha No Niwa, (some more here: http://goo.gl/nyw9s) are indeed being produced.  It's just figuring out how to get these to people so that they can be viewed, in a way that successfully removes of burned in context of the "anime-is-porn-isn't-it" stigma.

My comments are mostly on the referenced post below.

#morningdiscussion

comments.text:
In the end it really comes down to what exactly is meant by "mainstream" 
doesn't it? I think there are a lot of great stories with truly universal 
appeal that really deserve a wider audience. Naoki Urusawa's *Monster* 
comes to mind. Or even something like the first half of *Usagi Drop*, or 
the films of Mamoru Hosoda, which are nearly unknown in the West but have 
been a *big* hit with all the kids I've showed them to. I could go on and 
on. However if you're defining "mainstream" as "makes big bucks with 
standard Western business models," that is only ever going to be a very 
small slice of the anime pie (i.e.: Ghibli). Besides the issue is very much 
complicated by the fact that said Western business models are under siege 
and probably won't be around in any recognizable form for very much longer 
anyway.

in entertainment is what sort of things help us collectively vent desire, 
frustration, and everything else pent up during our daily take of societal, 
religious, and other demands. Japan has almost no significant influence of 
Christianity, so that's going to affect the acceptability of sexuality in 
various contexts, but, showing affection (even hugging really) is far more 
an informal thing in the US than it is historically in Japan. Directly 
expressing one's feelings, questioning authority, going off-script during 
specific circumstances, what employment can expect from you, what your 
understood duties are to family, even attitudes to intervening for the 
benefit of others is majorly different between the East and West. Shows 
here in the US can have things like sex or comedy or nudity or violence, as 
do some anime, but the lines they can/can't cross, what's taboo, what's 
"normal", what's "allowed", and most importantly, what's going to meet the 
desires of the viewer are incredibly different. In other words, you can't 
keep yourself 100% in the dark about Japanese culture and make any sense 
out of not only the content of anime, but also *why* that's the case.

It's really a complicated kind of thing.

captions.text:
AZ Rants is a segment where I take a
less structured and humorous approach

to look at any topic that crosses my mind
relating to the subject of anime and manga.

It contains my raw, biased opinion and is for the
purpose of creating debate and/or discussion,
so it shouldn't be taken too seriously.
Got that? Great, now shut up and listen.
If you count yourself as an anime fan, or even if you don't,

I'm sure it's common knowledge that anime
itself is a very obscure and niche hobby,
especially if you live in the West.

As a longtime avid anime fan, I wasn't always
the most open with my love for anime.
And, to an extent, I'm still not.

Not because I feel ashamed for liking
anime, but because, as it stands,
not many people in my real life actually have much interest in it,
and nor do most people, for that matter.
To put things in perspective, according to Google trends,

something like "Attack on Titan", which
has taken the anime world by storm,

is only just reaching the same amount of interest
that "One Piece" has held this entire time.

And this is just a small fraction that a super popular show
like "The Walking Dead" achieves when it's airing.

While many people know of anime, those who
actually indulge in it are few and far between.

But as someone who always tries to promote
anime and get as many people into it as possible,
I always keep coming back to one question:

Does anime as a medium ever stand a chance
of becoming mainstream here in the West?
Well.... yes, and no.

It's a pretty simple question, but not as
simple to answer as many may first think.

And to so would draw from a lot of
elements from all my previous rants.

But, let's start by addressing the biggest issue it has that
will stop it from ever being acknowledged by the masses.

Animation is simply not a widely accepted
medium that can tell a mature story.
Why would that matter? Well, let's look at it this way.

If we look at the most popular and critically-
acclaimed shows coming out of The States,

you'd see that nearly all of them are
garnered towards a mature audience.

The "Breaking Bad"s, "The Walking Dead"s, the
"Game of Thrones", The "Dexter"s, the "Mad Men".
All these shows are far from child-friendly,
and for anime to ever stand a chance of being acknowledged,
I believe that it's this huge, untapped audience here that will do it.
The problem is that, to the western audience,
any piece of animation is simply not an option to tell a mature story,
being simply shackled to the word "cartoon,"
given the options of either a children's show or an adult comedy.
It's a shame because, when I look at my critically-acclaimed anime,
I don't just see its potential compared to other anime;
I see "Fate/Zero" as our answer to "Game of Thrones",
"Baccano!" comparable to Quentin Tarantino movies,
"Highschool of the Dead" as a response to "The Walking D—"
[laughs]
Okay, but seriously...

Anime has proven itself time and time
again that it can tell a mature story,

and has arguably some of the best
examples of mature animation out there.

But, in all honesty, it also has its own
childish image to contend with over here.
All this roots back to the time of the anime boom in the early 2000s,

the time when "Pokémon" ruled the world,
girls were looking up to their "Sailor Moon"s,
and guys were getting hyped on their "Dragonball Z"s.
The closest anime ever comes to being mainstream

is normally through a 4Kids dub of a children's
show, or through a popular shonen,
which only further cements the childish image that it's given.

Though, let's not forget the other
quite-big image that it has to deal with.
Anime is weird!
Yes, it is weird.

Even among some of the more
toned-down stories we know anime has,

it's still buried between the mountains of moe-blob
otaku pandering shows coming out every season

and the stuff that would raise eyebrows if
you even try to describe the plot of them.
Sure, this is part of the reason we love it,

but it's even worse for the public eye because,
to them, that's all that's seemingly out there.

All they see when they look at anime
is a clique of odd, unsociable nerds
watching some bizarre high school girl fetish show,

complete with perverse masturbation material with
a plot that's pretty much impossible to understand.
The public image for anime isn't the greatest,

and it's pretty much the same image that hardcore
gamers or "Star Trek" fans had to deal with in the past.
And for anime to stand any chance of becoming mainstream,
it needs to break out of this preconception the public has of it.
And, to be honest, I'm not sure if it can yet.

Unless we get super lucky and have
something like "Attack on Titan" air on HBO,

or "Wolf Children" gets super popular in theaters,
we need to look at anime as a whole.
As much as we would like to think that there are anime for all ages,
honestly, it's not as mature as we make it out to be.

Yes, the image of cartoons is highly inaccurate
for the diverse medium that anime is,
but in terms of primary demographic, it's still mostly for teenagers.

It's a rarity for anime to not be set in high school or
have high school-age characters for their protagonists.

Fanservice, as I pointed out in my previous rant,
is more glorified and plentiful than it ever was,

and the genre that is by far the most
popular is still the shonen genre.

Even in terms of movies, there isn't really anything that can
match the top, critically-acclaimed stuff that Hollywood offers,

unless it just falls back to the family-
friendly, Disney-esque type films,

which doesn't really change any preconceptions
about animation as a medium of storytelling.

As it stands, anime's just not mature enough yet to break
out of its pre-existing image of the general populace.

There's still too much reliance on
stories that revolve around high school,
gratuitous fanservice in abundance,
not enough anime that can appeal to the mature audience.

And one "Attack on Titan" isn't going
to change the mass opinion alone.
Anime simply is not ready yet.
Though, that's not to say that it never will be.

Recently, there have been snippets of news here and
there that hint at a possible future for anime over here.
The highly-successful "Little Witch Academia" Kickstarter campaign,

which managed to completely obliterate
its Kickstarter goals within days

despite the fact that it did so poorly in Japan they
had to cancel live events due to low ticket sales.

This follows news of a live-action adaptation
for Naoki Urasawa's "Monster" coming to HBO,

along with a Toonami revival that, so far,
has pretty much exceeded all expectations.
Hollywood, it seems, is also slowly starting to take interest

after producing the highly-anime-influenced
"Pacific Rim", even though it did tank domestically,

alongside rumors of Leonardo DiCaprio
turning down a role in the new "Star Wars"
to work on a "Robotech" movie with Tobey Maguire,
and Warner Bros. announcing a new live-action "Death Note" movie.

The prospects for an increased awareness
of anime are certainly looking up,
but this actually leads me to my final question.

Do we, as a fanbase, actually want anime
to become popular and mainstream?
There's an irony in my own personal opinion,

since I never would have started this
YouTube channel if anime were more popular
and I had friends to talk about it with.
But, just think about it for a second.

Imagine a place where people stand around water coolers
discussing the newest events in "Attack on Titan",
where you can walk down the street with a "Madoka Magica" t-shirt
without having to explain that it's a dark and edgy show,

where Fox News are debating the controversial
violence portrayed in "Elfen Lied".

The effect of making something mainstream may seem like a
simple case of "More Popularity = More Money = Better Stuff,"
but things don't always work out like that.

If we look at another part of nerd culture
that's become mainstream, gaming,
we see that the popularity spike didn't mean that independent artists
were allowed more creative freedom to do what they wanted,

but instead, we now see the control of
select multi-billion mega-corporations

funding the same gritty, realistic war shooters
every year to fit within their business models.

While, arguably, the majority of the
creative stuff is coming from the little guys.
Sure, there is still some great stuff coming out,

but what kind of change would anime
see if it were to become popular?

Right now, we are a cult -- a niche fanbase
within an already niche part of geek culture.

And while there are plenty of plus sides
to finding out that our strange little hobby

has suddenly exploded in popularity
and is now understood by the masses,

we would lose the uniqueness we shared
when this was just some obscure little thing
that was only appreciated by other people like you.

Yes, it's filled with strange archetypes
and tropes that put other people off,
but it's these characteristics that we all love about anime.

As much as I complain about the
clichés and tropes of anime sometimes,
if I stay away from it for too long, I secretly crave it.

I want my tsunderes, my insane shonen
power-ups, my short high school skirts.

And while it may be great for the medium
we love to be acknowledged by the masses,

is it worth it at the cost of watering down these characteristics
that drew us to the medium in the first place?

Would it change a lot from the thing
that we know and love at this moment?

And would the fanbase we're in now change from the people
in this little corner of geekdom we're all connected with?
So, I'm asking you guys now.
Do you want anime to become mainstream?

Leave a comment or video response for
your chance to get featured in my next rant.

Anyway, that's it for me now, though,
so with your response to my last rant,
what do you think about fanservice in anime?

[42believers]
Fanservice... a topic that makes many
female anime fans groan in disgust
as they rant and rave about how degrading it is to anime,
not to mention women in general,
and how it's the most evil thing in the entire world, which must be...

Hey guys! Gigguk here. Now, you may
notice I'm somewhere different today.
And, well, that's because I'm on holiday in Thailand.
Why am I in Thailand?
Well, 'cause I'm... Asian and Thai...
Yeah...

If you enjoyed this rant, be sure to check
out my other rants and the featured video
for some more interesting discussion videos.

And, as always, you can find me on Facebook
and Twitter in the description below.
Anyway, that's it for me now, though.

So, I'm still waiting on my voice actors for
"EvAbridged 4.0", so that'll be out later.
But, until then, I've been Gigguk, and I'll see you all next time.
